bug.short_desc: Add gutter marker for deow members in an aspect

long_desc.thetext:
All of the crosscutting members in an aspect have gutter markers to show their cross-references (advice has the "advises" marker, ITDs have the "declared on" marker). All except declare warning / error that is, which don't currently have a gutter marker.
For consistency we should add one which shows all of the warning / error locations matched by the statement. This information is already in the cross-references view and hence available in the structure model.
*** Bug 154568 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

An additional reason for implementing this enhancement is that if you've written a declare error or warning statement and you want to know how many places it affects you have to bring up the cross references view and count them yourself (if this is many it can get tedious). However, with advises one can just hover over the gutter marker and it will say how many markers there are on that line.
Also, many people work with views like the outline/cross references closed to give the most space to the editor. When writing deow statements it would be nice to get immediate feedback as to whether they've matched anything rather than having to open these views or scroll down in the problems view to see if the message you've chosen is there.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: [compiler][null] evolved variables correlation involving a boolean flag

long_desc.thetext: This test case is somewhat similar to the one of bug 134933. There is a supplementary difficulty in the way err gets modified (the 'err false implies s not null' property is not affected by the second assignment, which does not occur if err is false, but this calls for a proper analysis of the flow relative to err valuation). Our current implementation cannot cope with that class of problems, and solving them calls for radical changes. To my best knowledge, this is not in plan.

bug.short_desc: Cannot get parameter group from getParameterDefn method

long_desc.thetext:
Description: IScalarParameterDefinitionTask.getParameterDefn(name) cannot get parameter group
Steps to reproduce: Try to get parameter group from call IScalarParameterDefinitionTask.getParameterDefn(name) method. e.g.paramDefn=task.getParameterDefn( "p4_group" );
Expected result: Return parameter group instance.
Actual result: Return null.
Fixed.
Now it can get parameter group but it cannot get parameters defined inside parameter group which worked in before codes. reopen it.

Engine will return the parameter with the specified param_name whether it is a *ScalarParameter* or *ParameterGroup*. return null if no *ScalarParameter* or *ParameterGroup* has the same param_name.
Fixed.
Verified

bug.short_desc: [update] "Select Required" chooses SDK when Runtime is needed

long_desc.thetext:
On the Target Management Update site (http://downloads.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/updates) we have the following features and dependencies:
TM SDK (includes TM Core, docs, sources and everything else) TM Core TM Ssh (requires TM Core)
When I select "TM Ssh" an press "select required", I get the TM SDK selected. I'd expect to get only the TM Core selected since I dont't want sources and ISV docs.
I've tried changing the site.xml files to change categories, sort order etc. but the problem persists -- Update Manager always selects SDK as dependency, although the Core would be sufficient.
Wore general, if a feature X has dependencies Y,Z - and there are multiple possible features which are able to serve Y,Z - then the update manager should choose the one which serves Y,Z + and fewest other additional features.

The problem is still there in Eclipse 3.2.1 on the Callisto site: For instance,
* Select "Enabling Features" > "Apache Commons Logging" --> Error is shown that log4j is missing * Click "Select Required" --> 6 (!) Features are selected, including full WST (!), EMF, XSD, GEF (!), VE
Looking at this, the "Select Required" feature is pretty unusable, and user has to select the required features manually. I find this pretty annoying.
Is a fix for this planned as part of a larger picture improving the Update Manager? Or what's going to happen with this bug? Do you want help for this?
Marking this as a bug now, because what it does to Enabling Features on the Callisto Discovery Site is certainly buggy.

As per the Europa conference call on Wed 18-Oct-2006, I wanted to bring this bug to the attention of cross-project.inbox and the Europa leaders...
On http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Europa_Simultaneous_Release it was mentioned that Europa should have both SDK and Runtime packages on its discovery site. I had mentioned that because of this bug, when selecting a runtime sub-feature, "Select Required" would not work at all if SDK packages were on the same site.
Since Europa wants to go that route, I consider this issue as major. Anyone wants to look at it?

The minimum that UM must do, is when a feature is listed both explicitly and contained in a wrapper, the explicit dependency must be chosen.
Folks, this is really a major issue for Europa. See also bug 175004 for a similar (but harder to solve) issue with bundle dependencies.
Dejan, this looks important for 3.3

As discussed in the Europa meeting at EclipseCon, I verified again that the "Select Required chooses SDK when Runtime is needed" issue is still there, and is still a major issue that I think should be fixed. I checked with eclipse-SDK-3.3M5eh-win32 on WinXP SP2.
The issue is most easily reproducable from the TM update site (fast and small), but it is also visible on the Europa Discovery site. On the TM update site (http://download.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/updates), select "RSE Runtime Only > RSE Local Services" and press "Select Required". --> RSE SDK is chosen instead of RSE Runtime.
What's interesting is that the bug seems to be sensitive to very minor modifications. For instance, I could NOT reproduce the issue on the TM milestone site (http://download.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/updates/milestones) but I could reproduce it on the TM nightly testUpdate site (http://download.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/testUpdates) which is almost the same.
On the Europa Discovery site, it is currently shown when selecting "Test and Performance > TPTP Profiling for Web Applications" and choosing "Select Required". --> The WTP SDK is selected instead of the WTP Runtime.
Although right now the issue not very imminent for Europa (coarse granularity, so relatively few inter-project dependencies) I expect it to become more problematic soon, when more projects add their SDKs to the site (e.g. BIRT and CDT do not currently expose their SDKs on the Europa site; Dependency on those features will also be subject to getting SDK instead of runtime).
See comment #4 for a minimal fix that I think must be implemented for Europa. In order to more clearly indicate that this is a major bug and not just an enhancement request, I changed the title (Previous title was: Select Required shold choose the minimal dependency if more options exist)
Dejan, do you have any comment regarding if this is feasible for 3.3 or not? It's an important issue for Europa.
Martin, does this mean users that use the "select required" option may be downloading lots of packages they don't actually need?

'Add required' function is an honest attempt, it was not meant to be correct in 100% of cases.
The logic in this function is touchy. I will change it unless there is a patch by the community that proves to be solid. Update currently has one active committer (myself) so do not expect much for 3.3.

(In reply to comment #9) > The logic in this function is touchy. I will change it unless there is a patch
Did you mean: "I will not change it" ?
Yes, sorry - it was a long day :-).

(In reply to comment #8) > Martin, does this mean users that use the "select required" option may be > downloading lots of packages they don't actually need?
Yes. Exactly. They get lots of source features and isv docs.
Perhaps for the concrete problem of SDK vs. Runtime, there is a rather simple fix that does not need to be very generic.
The problem that UM "select required" needs to solve is: given bundle (or feature) X, who includes X? - It looks like right now, UM iterates over the features and as soon as a feature A is found which includes X (at any nesting level) it is taken.
Given that typically, an SDK has its corresponding runtime feature as an "included feature" it would probably suffice if: - as soon as feature A is found with the current algorithm, UM checks the included features of A - and tries if the one which happens to hold the bundle in question is also listed in site.xml. So this would not really be a change of the algorithm, but rather some kind of post-processing to fine-tune the result once a feature candidate is found.
I must admit, though, that this idea is just out of my observations and I have not looked at the code at all.

Martin, a question for you:
If we find Runtime to contain the require feature as well as SDK AND it has less plug-ins to bring in, but SDK is newer (say, 1.0.1 over 1.0.0 for Runtime), should less plug-ins win or newer version?

Here is a concrete example from the update site listed above:
org.eclipse.rse.sdk_1.0.1.v20061215a-oyabpho6o4KtC0S
org.eclipse.rse.core_1.0.1.v20061129------AXrVWXgmmZ
Update can pick either of these and satisfy the requirement. Core is smaller (less plug-ins) but SDK is newer (qualifier is lexicographically 'better'). Should we ingore the qualifier?

Ignore the previous - it does not matter.
Here is the fix that I think will work:
1) If the two (or more) candidates to select have the same ID, pick the newer 2) If the two (or more) candidates to select have different IDs (different features), calculate total number of plug-ins they will bring and pick one with the least number.
I tested the fix on the TM update site and it picked the runtime, not SDK. I also tested on the Europa site and everything seemed to work well.
Created an attachment (id=63673) The fix
Done.

(In reply to comment #13) > If we find Runtime to contain the require feature as well as SDK AND it has > less plug-ins to bring in, but SDK is newer (say, 1.0.1 over 1.0.0 for > Runtime), should less plug-ins win or newer version?
If feature A includes B (and only B is required), I cannot see how A can be newer than B. It must include the exact same verbatim copy. I would consider an update site.xml that lists an SDK with a new runtime, and also separately lists an old runtime but not the new one, broken (can't be intentional IMHO). Thus I don't think the version makes any difference. Also, the examples you posted are old -- the algorithm for computing qualifiers has changed with 3.3M6.
Therefore, the algorithm you described looks good to me. Of course multiple versions of the same feature need to be subject to version constraints as specified in the requiring features, but I guess if these are not met than it cannot be a candidate anyways.

bug.short_desc: Different warning seettings for different source folders in the same project

long_desc.thetext:
I have two source folders in my project, one for the main source, and one for JUnit testcases.
It would be nice to to have a more relaxed warning setting for the testcases, e.g. I don't want to write doc comments on all test methods (the test methods are not part of the public API, they are only public for technical reasons).

bug.short_desc: ListView.getIconSize

long_desc.thetext:
ListView.getIconSize which states:
"Gets the preferred icon size that matches the density style. The style must be one of SWT.HIGH, SWT.MEDIUM, or or SWT.LOW.
Parameters: style - the size style. Only SWT.HIGH, SWT.MEDIUM, and SWT.LOW can be used. "
However, these density constants are not defined in the class SWT but in the class ListView itself. The prefix "SWT." should be removed. Other methods' docs don't have this bug.
This bug is in eSWTFullSpec-v20060803.
Fixed in spec project. Rebuild and reposting of JavaDoc for Rel. 1.0 still required.

bug.short_desc: [nls][doc] Missing user docs on how to use SSL

long_desc.thetext: It's unclear how SSL can be enabled for dstore connections. - Where can I get an SSL certificate? - What is the RSE SSL Preference page good for? - How do I export the key to the server? - How do I enable SSL in the server properties?
Documentation is a high priority for 1.0.1 - we can't offer our users features that are not documented, and expect feedback from them. I'd love to see this for 1.0.1
Pushing out to M6 for now. Who would know how to use the SSL functionality?
User Doc delivery is slightly after M6, so deferring to early M7.
Provided a user's guide section entitled "Working with SSL".
Reopening until we get the instructions a bit clearer.
Updated with more detail.

bug.short_desc: Eclipse fails to load with jdk7 b01

long_desc.thetext:
With jdk7 as my default java version, when I run eclipse 3.2, the splash screen appears for a few seconds, then goes away, and a litte window informs me that an error has occured, and where the log file is (which is actually very helpful - thanks to those responsible for this elegant error handling).
jdk7 b01 is supposed to only really differ from recent jdk6 build in version strings, so I'm guessing a new version identification might affect something.
Workaround: Add to eclipse.ini
-vm C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0\bin\javaw.exe

The issue is we do not have a jdk7 profile to set the execution environment of OSGi. This causes the framework to fail to resolve and the IllegalStateException to occur. The IllegalStateException error message is very bad or non-existant. This has been fixed in bug 151413 along with the NPE in EclipseStarter that happens when the execution environment is not set.
JavaSE 7 is a ways out so I do not really want to add a profile to support it just yet. Instead I have added code to allow the framework to fallback to an earlier profile. In this case it will fall back to JavaSE 6 profile.
If you want to use your own java profile for JavaSE 7 then you can set the osgi.java.profile system property to specify a URL to your own custom profile.

Thanks (for the fixes & the info), I now have eclipse 3.2 running on jdk7.
Simplest workaround (for anyone else reading this bug report) is to create or edit eclipse.ini, and add the following two lines (you might already have the -vmargs line):
-vmarg -Dosgi.java.profile=jar:file:///eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.2.0.v20060601.jar!/JavaSE-1.6.profile
But here is what I actually did:
1) Searched for examples profiles, found them in org.eclipse.osgi_3.2.0.v20060601.jar
2) Copied JavaSE-1.6.profile out of there, to my c:\eclipse directory
3) renamed it to JavaSE-1.7.profile
4) edited it so that the last lines now read
J2SE-1.5,\ JavaSE-1.6,\ JavaSE-1.7 osgi.java.profile.name = JavaSE-1.7
5) altered c:\eclipse\eclipse.ini so that it contained (amongst other things)
-vmargs -Dosgi.java.profile=file:///eclipse/JavaSE-1.7.profile
*** Bug 176927 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: [reorg] Move should only do validateEdit on files that really changed

long_desc.thetext:
3.3
Moving multiple files calls validate edit on all files. To be correct, it should only call validateEdit on files that also change (for example CU's where the package statement is changed).
See disabled Test org.eclipse.jdt.ui.tests.refactoring.ValidateEditTests.testMoveCU2()
*** Bug 157827 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The test case looks wrong to me. It moves cu1 and file from org.test to org.test, which is not possible to do in the UI.
When I change otherFragment to org.test2, or when I create otherFragment in another source folder, then everything is fine.
Moving to 3.4 to fix and enable the test case (make two versions: move to org.test2 and move to src2/org.test).
seems to be fixed in I20071127. Test enabled again.

bug.short_desc: [Regression]Error when modify the "datasetRow" to "row" as the same column

long_desc.thetext:
Details: Error when modify the "datasetRow" to "row" as the same column
Step: 1.New a sample datasource 2.New a dataset named sampleDB by "select * from CLASSICMODELS.CUSTOMERS" 3.Add a table, binding the data set and all the columns are added by auto. 4.Add a data item in detail, select name as "CUSTOMERNUMBER" in drop down list. 5.Open the expression editor and select "Available Data Set" - "sampleDB" - "CUSTOMERNUMBER". 6.Press OK and preview. It is OK. 7.Double click the data item and reopen the expression 8.Modify the content by "Available Column Binding" - "sampleDB" - "CUSTOMERNUMBER". 9.Click OK and preview.
Actual result: Error pop up.
Exception result: The error is because the data column name is conflict. For the edition before, the "Available Column Binding" will not appear the column of "CUSTOMERNUMBER". It can not appear the column.

please attach the report design. Is there a circular reference in the data binding expression? DtE should evaluate such an expression to invalid value when the expression right hand side calculation requires values from the current left hand side of the expression (circular referencing in calculation). DtE should log a warning when it can not find the row value to evaluate an expression. Model can add a semantic check to help designer, but DtE needs to handle such error condition since such error could happen in custom script where model won't be able to detect.
on the model side, when user try to create a new data binding column name that is already exists in the binding, it should throw exception so that UI can let user know such column name already exists in the binding.

DtE already has a check for circular reference. This happens in runtime.If the reference cycle is detected an exception will be thrown, and DtE will stop execution of the query.
Wenfeng, do you mean that DtE should continue to execute the query, even if the reference cycle is found.And those column bindings with circular reference should be evaluated to an invalid value?
Created an attachment (id=48350) datacolumn.rptdesign

This bug is a regression bug. I check the builder before, on step 8, the column of "CUSTOMERNUMBER" will not appear on the "Available Column Binding"-"sampleDB" list. Because it will bring a conflict on "datasetRow["CUSTOMERNUMBER"]" and "row["CUSTOMERNUMBER"]" in a same column name.

Fixed it.Because now we edit a data binding which isn't from a tableViewer,so we couldn't use the ComputeColumnExpressionFilter.We have to modify the ComputeColumnExpressionFilter.java to adapt a ComputeColumnHandle.
Verified and closed

bug.short_desc: Framework for Unit Tests

long_desc.thetext: I wanted to make unit tests for my W4T/RAP-Applikation. In my special case I need to call the resolve function on the W4Tcontext Class. I therefore need a test fixture, that handles a 'fake' initialisation of the Context, right? How do I go about that? Could it be possible, to pack the needed functionality in utility classes?

AFAIK there is no official thing for this yet. Inofficially, you'll find a project "org.eclipse.rap.rwt.test" in the CVS. This has a class RWTFixture. I copied this one into my test project and use it. That works well for me.

bug.short_desc: "Initialize diagram" action can not process links by class in case if source/target EReferences are isMany

long_desc.thetext:
Actually, the storeLinks.jetinc assumes that LinkByClass#getSource() instanceof EObject. In the case if it has higher multiplicity, links are ignore even if they are actualyy not n-ary.
E.g, in the UML2 class diagram Dependency has declared source/target as unbounded. Even with instance of binary link the result of Dependency#getSource() is List (probably with only one element), thus dependencies are effectively ignored by "Initialize Class diagram" Action.
Expected: storeLinks.jetinc takes into account the possibility of unbounded source/target metafeatures. Also it is seems to be not-critical to skip actual N-ary links, the binary instances should be processed correctly.
In particular, attached dependency.uml sample should be correctly processed by "Initialize diagram" action

Created an attachment (id=48266) UML model instance (2 classes and dependency link between)
Actually "init diagram action" from generated UML2 class diagram editor does not recreate dependency link between A and B.
Created an attachment (id=48267) Fixes the subj
commited

attachment.desc: UML model instance (2 classes and dependency link between)

bug.short_desc: [xmiInstantiator] Poseidon: Exceptions not supported

long_desc.thetext:
For Poseidon exceptions - modelled as raised signals for operations - are not assigned to the 'Exception' collection of Operation.
Mapping of exceptions in the XMI export for Poseidon are in a specific node 'UML:A_context_raisedSignal':
------------------------------------------ <XMI.content> ... <UML:A_context_raisedSignal> <UML:Operation xmi.idref='...'/> <UML:Exception xmi.idref='...'/> <UML:Operation xmi.idref='...'/> <UML:Exception xmi.idref='...'/> ... </UML:A_context_raisedSignal> </XMI.content> ------------------------------------------

Problem is solved.
- PoseidonAdapter::fixDesign() - improved tool mapping

bug.short_desc: Run As JUnit Test does nothing on a compilation unit

long_desc.thetext: When right-clicking on a .java file in the Navigator view and selecting Run As -> JUnit Test, nothing happens. Note: expanding the .java file in the Navigator view and doing the same operation on the class itself correctly starts the JUnit test.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 143849 ***

bug.short_desc: [CommonNavigator] Wizard ordering not controllable in popup

long_desc.thetext:
When a number of "new" Wizards with the same menuGroupId are contributed to the CommonNavigator they are always presented in the popup menu in alphabetical order rather than in the order that they were specified in the org.eclipse.ui.navigator.navigatorContent extension.
A use case, for example, would be to maintain consistancy Wizard ordering in the File/New main menu with their ordering in the Common Project Explorer popup.

There is a groupId attribute associated with the commonWizard element that will allow you to group related wizards together. While this isn't the same order as the perspective wizards under File > New, it can provide organization for related wizards.

(In reply to comment #1) > There is a groupId attribute associated with the commonWizard element that will > allow you to group related wizards together. While this isn't the same order as > the perspective wizards under File > New, it can provide organization for > related wizards. >
Yes I am using this feature, but, as you noted, this does not affect the ordering within the grouping.
When each of the new wizards represents an element in a hierarchial ordering such as New Project, Class, Field, etc., the loss of consistant ordering becomes very obvious.

Expand All - Expands all nodes in the Profiling Monitor view. CollapseAll - Collapses all nodes in the Profiling Monitor view. Expand Node - Expands all the selected node and its children in the Profiling Monitor view. Collapse Node - Collapses all the selected node and its children in the Profiling Monitor view.

bug.short_desc: [DiagramEditor] Provide visual cue about a diagram type and its editing mode

long_desc.thetext:
Feedback from recent user testing suggests that users were confused by editable vs. non-editable diagram feedback.
Inconsistent behaviour between editable and non-editable diagrams may confuse the user. Furthermore, users may not trust the user interface that provides inconsistent feedback.
To address, we recommend that we provide some information or feedback to reinforce diagram type and editing mode. Selection sets in non-editable diagrams should present unique feedback to reinforce available options. Visio, for example notes the diagram type adjacent to page in the diagram editor. Potential solutions include: a note, or embedded watermark, or populate a palette tray with system status feedback.

We need to make use of the status bar to display the edit mode like other Eclipse editors --> text editor.
X / Y location on the status bar would also be useful.

bug.short_desc: Hide expand/collapse handles when compartments have no contents

long_desc.thetext:
During recent usability testing, 4 out of 10 users had problems with list compartment visibility. Users were confused by list compartment expand and collapse functionality, and at times, were unclear if list compartments contained newly created content. A couple of users were wondering why if there were not compartment contents why the expand/collapse arrows were even present.
If there are no compartment contents, it would be more useful for users if the expand/collapse handles were not shown.

Created an attachment (id=49430) fix includes fixes for: 115905 and 156253
The fix for this issue includes fixes for Bug #115905 and Bug #156253. The issue described here is fixed with the use of listener to the semantic events. The drawback of this approach, and the only approach we can suggest to fix this, is that any "add" or "remove" semantic event will be caught by all collapsed compartments which refer to the same semantic element and each will update the number of its semantic children (although not all of them need to do this)
Moved to 2.0 as per discussion with Fred
Looks like we can resolve this one.

bug.short_desc: IStatus.getSeverity javadoc inconsistent with Status implementation

long_desc.thetext:
The javadoc for IStatus.getSeverity indicates that OK will be returned if the status has no children. The implementation for Status can return a status other than OK even though it has no children.
The javadoc for IStatus.getSeverity seems incorrect (or at least misleading).
Its a subtle distinction, but a MultiStatus object with no children returns an OK severity.
I see. Thanks for the clarification.

bug.short_desc: [ModelingAssistant] Add instructions/tips to action bars

long_desc.thetext:
Recent usability testing found that users were unable to determine what the action toolbar (ATB) on empty canvas meant and how it appeared. They were able to figure out how the diagram assist features that appeared on a diagram element but not the ones that appeared on a blank canvas.
Should a user be unable to determine the value of the action toolbar, it's constant appearance/disappearance/reappearance may annoy the user. If unused, the action toolbar will only contribute to visual noise and ultimately distract the user from the task at hand.
To help the user determine how the ATBs on blank canvas work, the pop-up balloon requires some form of affordance to prompt/educate/inform the user that the ATB is a diagram element creation assistance feature. Consider the inclusion of some instructional text, or a command label. A line of simple text with a small font made to look like hover text would not be too intrusive. The message string could read: "Click an icon to create a model element on the diagram". (Please develop all message strings with ID. )
Furthermore, the presence of instructional text or command labels could be managed in the same way it is managed on toolboxes and palettes. Users could configure the display of action tool bar label via a common diagram assistance option page.

bug.short_desc: BorderItemLocator never sets the size for side-affixed figures forcing all of them to have width=height=0

long_desc.thetext:

NOTE: There is workaround for this problem added into the NodeEditPart.javajet (searchable by bugzilla id). Once this will be fixed, workaround should be removed.

Created an attachment (id=53775) Suggested fix.
Michael, I have attached a patch. If you want to give it a try when you get a chance and let me know if it resolves your issues that would be great. I tried removing the generated line that was a workaround and it seems to work fine for me.

I committed the attached patch.
Border items always used their preferred size and could never be resized when something was added to a compartment in the border item or if a resizable editpolicy was installed and the user changed the size manually.
I updated the AbstractBorderItemEditPart.refreshBounds() method to pass the size stored in the view in the constraint to the BorderItemLocator. I updated the BorderItemLocator to use the size in the constraint given, unless it hadn't been set in which case it would continue to use the border item's preferred size.

bug.short_desc: WebServiceTestRegistry is tracking extensions using label attribute instead of ID

long_desc.thetext:
The WebServiceTestRegistry uses an extension's label attribute as the key to a hashtable for WebServiceTestExtensions. Although this is not causing any problems, it's not as clean as using the ID attribute. It also this makes the logic to merge test extension data defined from different plugins a bit more complicated (this behaviour is added in bug 153833)
This bug is opened to track this as a possible improvement for the future.
I agree. We shouldn't be doing any label comparisons. This is going to bit us with some language, so we should fix it up.

Label math is creepy and this is a good change to make, but I consider it outside of the scope of 1.5.1. There is no observable bug at play, and any unnecessary risk to 1.5.1 is best avoided. Deferred to 2.0. Let me know of any concerns.

I see this problem as having 2 parts. The first part is as stated originally, we are using labels to track WebServiceTestExtension. The side-effect of this is that we are persisting these label values as preferences as well, which is a problem if users switches locale on the same workspace. I'll post a patch shortly to address this part of the problem.
The second part of the problem is there are various places in our code (particularly those involving the UI) where we are passing these label values around and thus tieing the user's selection to the UI. I've opened bug 177610 to track this as a separate problem.

Created an attachment (id=60995) patch for jst.ws and jst.ws.ui
With this patch, the WebServiceTestRegistry will switch to using ID to catalog its extensions. Also the IDs will be used to persist the test facility preferences but we'll still continue to interpret old preference settings which uses label values.
Patch reviewed and committed. Will release later on today.
Patch released to WTP 2.0 as v200705022145.

bug.short_desc: NPE in BundleErrorReporter#validateSingleton

long_desc.thetext:
I20060816-1200
This looks like a dup of Bug 139968, but in the newest I-Build. After a workbench crash and a restart I got NPEs and thousands of compile errors. See attached screenshot. NPEs are:
java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.builders.BundleErrorReporter.validateSingleton(BundleErrorReporter.java:151) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.builders.BundleErrorReporter.validateBundleSymbolicName(BundleErrorReporter.java:134) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.builders.BundleErrorReporter.validateContent(BundleErrorReporter.java:88) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.builders.ManifestConsistencyChecker.checkManifestFile(ManifestConsistencyChecker.java:69) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.builders.ManifestConsistencyChecker.checkThisProject(ManifestConsistencyChecker.java:55) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.builders.ManifestConsistencyChecker.build(ManifestConsistencyChecker.java:40) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:607) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:162) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:196) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:225) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:228) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:247) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:280) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:145) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:208) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)
Created an attachment (id=48295) screenshot
To recompile my workspace I had to do a 'Clean all' and then restart eclipse.
Should be fixed now in CVS. Targeting for 3.3M2

Good catch, you are right. The validateBundleSymbolicName gets called before checking fModel for null. validateBundleSymbolicName calls validateSingleton, which will throw an NPE if the fModel is null. Good catch. Updated it in CVS. Changing target milestone to 3.3M5 to reflect the fix.

The changes have been committed to CVS.

bug.short_desc: Document that EcoreList.set( Object )/EStructuralFeature.Setting/eSet can't handle itself as input

long_desc.thetext:
Matthias,
This case is similar to Collection.addAll which is Javadoc'd as :
Adds all of the elements in the specified collection to this collection (optional operation). The behavior of this operation is undefined if the specified collection is modified while the operation is in progress. (This implies that the behavior of this call is undefined if the specified collection is this collection, and this collection is nonempty.)
So c.addAll(c) has undefined behavior and that's not much different from list.set(list). Adding a guard seems like something that all uses must pay, but the benefit is that a no-op ends up being just a no-op instead of the client noticing that what they are doing doesn't make sense and should be changed to literally do no operation. The same situation arises with eSet were we'have have to change the generated code to check for the argument being the same as the target. Again, a cost that all must pay, but for which none will benefit.
For this reason, we don't consider this a problem that is worth fixing and instead we expect clients simply not to do this. The client code will be better if it avoids doing this...

Ed,
Thanks for your response.
I used a PropertyDescriptor to create a CellEditor, similar but not the same as a PropertySheetEntry does. The CellEditor returns a list at the end of its editing. This is either the list it was instanciated with, if the selection dialog was not open, or a new list containing the selection. Either way, the result of the cell editor is the new value of the PropertySource. I can not decide and I do not care how the CellEditor reached it's conclusion about the new values, I just set the result it returns to the Property. Setting the same values to a Property should not change them. I think we agree about that. I noticed that if I just activate the CellEditor, but don't open the dialog, the value all of the sudden is empty. I did quite some debugging before I found the reason for this behaviour.
Now you say, that's not the lists responsibility. I don't really see why a basic set-method should have an undefined case. The performance cost of a safeguard in this method will be practically nonexistent. I value the productivity cost much higher. Every single user will have to consider this nonintuitive and undocumented behaviour. Obviously by now at least one user did not. After I found out about the problem I showed the set method to some other programmers, and almost nobody could say rightout that there can be a problem at all. This is why I really think there should be a safeguard.

Matthias,
I know you think so, that's why you opened the bug. But clearly I do not, which is why I returned it as won't fix...
As I explained already, if it were just the list's test, that would not be such a big deal to add, although, ask yourself, why didn't AbstractList do that too for addAll? (Note that different implementations have different behavior when trying to do this, so it's rather a nasty problem too.) But the same argument can and will be applied to the behavior of eSet, i.e., why can't I do o.eSet(f, o.eGet(f))? And a number of people have complained about that case, but you're the first in 5 years to complain about this set method on the list; for the eSet case, the client code was always improved by simply removing the eSet call. To solve that problem the same way, we'd need to change the code generation pattern and that has a byte code cost for all clients. In other words, it's a cost that all will pay and yet few will benefit.
Given that now you know, you can either create a copy of the list for isMany features, you can not bother to set the value back since you are directly editing the state of the model, or you can avoid a pointless expense with your own == test. All these seem better than to incur an addition expense (granted small) on everyone else, just so you can blindly do a no-op operation.
Note too, that you can't be completely oblivious to what the cell editor does because if the cell editor decides to return list.subList(1, 3) that too would not work and yet seems reasonable at a glance. To solve this problem, one might argue that we could or should make a copy of the argument list before clearing the target list...
And on the point of the action being a no-opn, it's important to consider that any change in value will currently produce a notification, even if it will just be a touch notification because the value is set to the current value. So this case too ought to produce a touch notification since setting a single value to itself will certainly do that. Making it a no-op is an inconsistency.
At this point, I'm not convinced that adding the test has enough value to justify it so I'll reduce the severity to trivial and I'll instead use this bugzilla to add a Java doc comment saying that setting a value to iself has undefined behavior, much like what the List.addAll method says. I know that most folks don't typically bother to read what the documentation says, but as least if it's there it's working as documented.
So to be really clear, I don't consider this a problem that should be fixed with a code change, because the logic for doing so will be extended to the generated eSet and that's most definitely not something I'm willing to do.
The javadoc changes to EStructuralFeature.Setting.set an EObject.eSet has been committed to CVS.

bug.short_desc: move model tests to use a create and compare strategy

long_desc.thetext:
A comment in bug 141730:
"Also I'm concerned about how bloated all the tests are that verify anything to do with the structure model. If we need to do much more of this they should move to a create and compare strategy, like the weave messages tests - where we store the expected output on disk. Normally running the test creates some output and compares it with the output on disk reporting discrepancies, but the tests can also be run in a mode that regenerates the expected output."
Raising this enhancement to cover this.
The infrastructure has already been committed as part of comment #11 of bug 145963, however the existing tests should be moved over to the new structure.

Created an attachment (id=48298) moving existing model tests to use new structure
This zip file contains the following:
- modelTests-ajdt-core.txt: apply to the org.aspectj.ajdt.core project. This adds a call to report the model info if there are compilation errors. This is used in one of the model tests which uses declare error.
- modelTests-tests.txt: apply to the tests project.
- aspectpath.jar: put in tests\model\pr141730_3 if this jar was corrupted in the modelTests-tests.txt patch
- inpath.jar: put in tests\model\pr141730_4 if this jar was corrupted in the modelTests-tests.txt patch
Together these patches rewrite the existing model tests to fit in with the new structure committed as part of bug 145963.
Note that the tests use the JDTLikeHandleProvider from bug 141730 as these handles are consistent over different test runs on different os.

patches are in. I know the JDTlike handle provider makes things easier to test - so we really must make it the default if tests rely on it, otherwise we aren't testing what AJDT will be doing. Has it been activated in AJDT yet? We are waiting for confirmation that it is fine there before making it the default in AJ.

Created an attachment (id=48364) patch to remove unwanted tests
Apply this patch to the tests project.
This patch removes all the unwanted files/tests which are no longer required since moving the model tests.
patches committed.

In response to "Has it been activated in AJDT yet?" the answer is "no". I'm just working on running the AJDT tests with the JDTLikeHandleProvider and will add comments/patches regarding this to that enhancement (bug 141730).

Some comments on the model tests....
1. If the format of the reporting in AsmManager changes then the tests will fail in their comparison. The files against which to compare can be regenerated, however, the tests currently assume that the reporting dumps out both the model and the relationships and consequently tests both at the same time. If the formatting changes then it is necessary for both to still be tested
2. As mentioned, the JDTLikeHandleProvider has been used to ensure compatibility across different test runs and os. The one thing to look out for is the numbering. Currently, if there is more than one before advice in an aspect then they are numbered xxxx$1 and xxxx$2. The $1 and $2 are used in the handles. It is assumed that this is consistent over different test runs (note it is the byteCodeName which is used to get the count number)

One thought about the consistency is to use sourcelocations rather than handles in the relationship map part of the test. This would require adding another IModelFilter method to process the handle. Unfortunately, the implementation of this method in TestFilter would be to get the hierarchy, ask it for the ipe corresponding to the given handle and then ask this ipe for its sourcelocation (which would then need to be processed to have "TEST_SANDBOX" rather than the absolute path). This is on the way to being back where we started with the walking of the hierarchy. The one difference being that its all hidden within the test infrastructure rather than each test having to write it all out individually.

I was surprised that the existing debug dump mechanism was used for creating the expected output - if the dump format changes then, as you say, the tests will break. But as long as we know the dump format is important, we won't make unnecessary changes to it.
On the problem with the relationships comparison - is it not intended that the JDT handles will be highly robust things that can be relied upon? Returning to source locations again would seem like a step backwards...

Created an attachment (id=48566) adding a comment to AsmManager.reportModelInfo
Apply this patch to the asm project.
patch from comment #9 committed.
All work to be done on this has been committed, therefore closing as fixed.

Created an attachment (id=48693) patch to ensure model tests work on linux
Currently testNewIProgramElementMethods_pr141730() does't work on linux as the directory is PR141730_1 and it's looking for pr141730_1. This patch fixes this by renaming the directory (since the expected file needs the same name as the directory).
Apply this patch to the tests project.

that kind of patch doesnt apply nicely on windows - at least it didn't for me. I've done the rename manually, deleting the folder, committing the delete, recreating it, committing the recreate - please try it on Linux now.
Yes, this is now working on Linux.

bug.short_desc: "Keep Alive" does not work in the Automatable Services Framework out of process strategy

long_desc.thetext: The Keep Alive option to reuse an instance of out-of-proc Eclipse appears in the code base and documentation but does not work. This functionality would faciliate more use of TPTP in enterprise test tools. There is also the problem that if you DO try to use it, your execution will never start or return, and you need to kill errant processes and restart the AC before using services again. This defect was found during product development within IBM.

Christophe, Scott used to be the owner of the AUtomation services. Assign this to the new owner of automation.
Thanks

There are major performance implications in fixing this defect. Test automation providers and services can leverage off of the ASF for test execution and result interogation. An automation service could be launching multiple, successive, tests using the ASF. There will be significant performance improvements if each test that is run does not require a new instance of headless Eclipse to be launched. These performance improvements offer significant value in an automation scenario where timely suite runs are important. This functionality would be leveraged off of for IBM test automation solutions.

bug.short_desc: [actions] Annotation to disable sort on enums

long_desc.thetext: It would be nice if Eclipse had a Java annotation to disable sorting on a particular enum. All others could still be sorted with the menu 'Source->Sort Members...'.

Since sorting isn't done in JDT Core we, UI could do this but not sure whether we should introduce the annotation or JDT Core.
Sounds like yet another candidate of our discussed "annotation" mechanism.
There is alreayd a dialog that asks if you want to sort enum constants. Isn't that good enough?

(In reply to comment #2) > There is alreayd a dialog that asks if you want to sort enum constants. Isn't > that good enough? >
No. Most enums I want sorted, but the few that map to database constants, I do not. The current system is all-or-none.
To be honest, 'Sort Members' isn't on the top of our list for additional features. We would like to keep the feature as simple as possible. Setting to later and helpwanted.

bug.short_desc: [CheatSheet] action which launches a dialog does not complete cheatsheet step

long_desc.thetext: If a cheatsheet item has an action that launches a modal dialog, and the flags dialog=true and skip=true are set, and the user performs the action (versus skipping it), the cheatsheet follows into the dialog. But the step from which the action was launched is not completed, it appears as the current step in the dialog sidebar, and the only option left to the user to progress is to skip the step (that actually they just performed). This does not make sense - performing the action should (in this case) launch the dialog and also cause the action to be completed, and the next item should appear as the current one in the cheatsheet.

I've noticed this also. I think that it would be better if launching the dialog marked the step as completed and if the dialog is cancelled the cheatsheet should reset the step back to the step which lanuched the dialog.

What if the step says something like "Open dialog X, enter information Y, then click Ok." ?
There are some cases where this is desirable, and some where it is not. It is really up to the scope of the command. If the command is, for example, "openProjectDialog" then it should finish once the dialog is opened. On the otherhand if it says "createNewProject", then it should finish once the project is created.
So right now as it is, there is some control over this behavior already. If you have a command that runs you through an entire wizard, you can write a new command that will do the same but complete right away. However this is not very friendly.
Perhaps we can add add new API to allow the cheat sheet author to specify whether the step should complete immediately upon starting the command, or only after the command has completed. Any thoughts Chris?

"new API to allow the cheat sheet author to specify whether the step should complete immediately upon starting the command" - yes, this is what I had in mind. Then both scenarios are catered for explicity. Are there any other scenarios?

I concur with the new API, such as another attribute on the command/action since the next item or subitem may or may not relate to the dialog which was opened. To handle both cases we need the cheatsheet author to specify whether or not to advance when the dialog is launched.

bug.short_desc: just moving the mouse causes flicker

long_desc.thetext: The grid seems to redraw itself excessively. Just moving the mouse around on it causes a redraw. It does this even if you overload the mouseMove and MouseTrack events. I tested this by putting breakpoints into the onPaint function.
This is intentional. The grid is redrawn as you cross a cell boundary (and sometimes within a cell) to allow for hover effects.

I still fill like this is a bug because the normal swt.table does not have this issue. (Does it not allow hover effects?) By hover effects, do you mean per-cell tooltips or something else? We should still be able to shut off the redraw on mouseMove. And it should be off by default if the user never specifies any hover effects. And in general, the table should not redraw itself unnecessarily. With hover effects, it only needs to redraw a the portion of the table that was hovered over. I believe in most cases specifying a small region that needs to be repainted would be sufficient.

A hover effects include any change to the drawing of a cell if the mouse is over it. The user does not specify hover effects. Those are either performed (or not) by the renderers.
Yes, the table should be able to better limit the redrawing to only the effected areas. That is a performance related issue that will be dealt with much later in the dev cycle. This behavior does not seem to adversely effect either the visuals or the straight performance of the table (unless you are using an older SWT version). Are you being impacted by this now?
I'm not being bothered by this in a performance-critical way. It's just the flashing of the table as it's redrawn that bothers me. It looks unprofessional.

Ah. What version of SWT are you on? 3.0? Double buffering was added to 3.1 (I think its was 3.1) that eliminates this flashing.
Alternatively, if you are only seeing the flashing of the border then you are seeing bug 150274.
Good call. Bug 150274 is exactly what I'm seeing. I guess all the other controls I'm using just don't redraw enough to make it noticable.
I've made some changes that minimize this flicker. Theres a new build on the nebula site. Please try it out.

The most recent changes have improved things significantly, though I still see flicker when the mouse enters/leaves the control. Rub the mouse back and forth on the border. Also, I cannot see that bug 150274 has anything to do with it as I see the flicker in 3.3 m1.

bug.short_desc: [import rewrite] organize imports removes header comments
Ability to change row header text

long_desc.thetext: To use the RowRenderer requires overloading both paint and computeSize. These functions are compicated enough that a user has to copy the originals from the source and then modify them. Making custom strings, which will be the case 99%, should not be that difficult. What can we do to make it so the user only has to change "String num" in one place? What can we do to make it so that the user does not have to copy the source for defaultRowRenderer in the majority of circumstances?
I don't expect the majority of users to create their own renderers. Can you explain what you mean by making custom strings?

For my table usage, I'm rendering a view in a large table. Picture a 2d grid of 1000000 x 1000000. I'm showing a 100x100 window of that. Each dimension on the grid is a protien or nucleotide, meaning that each row or column has a chemical base represented by a letter. I need that character in my headers as well as the index of whatever cell in that million by million grid that I'm viewing.
I think it would be quite common to want to display characters in one dimension. Most spreadsheet applications have incrementing letters in one dimension.

Its Monday so you have to excuse me but I'm not following 100%. Are you talking about row headers? You want something other than the normal row numbers to appear there? If thats what you are after then I do have some plans to make that easier. I'm still contemplating the exact API, but I expect to have a method on GridItem like setHeaderText(String). That would override the normal row numbers.
A screenshot would help alot.

Created an attachment (id=48309) note the row headers
The row headers here pull a letter from a string at whatever position we happen to be viewing.
Ok cool. Thanks for the screenshot. So would GridItem.setHeaderText(String) essentially eliminate the need for you to create your own row header renderer?

GridItem.setHeaderText(String) should work find for me, assuming you can call it more than once per GridItem.
BTW, I think that the documentation needs to explicitly clarify that items are, for the most part and as I understand it, rows. It should explain why we call them "items". Also, I think that the "position" parameter of items should be explained as "column". It's confusing to new users otherwise.
I've added GridItem.setHeaderText(String) to simplify the use case. Please try the new build on the Nebula site.

bug.short_desc: import cannot be resolved

long_desc.thetext:
My plugin project implements JUnit test cases for other plugins. Each of the plugins being tested is referenced in the manifest plugin dependencies. When I build the project, I get an error "the import <package name> cannot be resolved"
I have confirmed that the plugin that implements the package does indeed export the package, and that the plugin is installed in the workspace. Using the PDE plug-ins view, I confirm that the plugin is active, and the manifest shows that the package is exported.
And still the build of the JUnit test plugin gets an error that the package cannot be resolved.
Possibly related -- if I use the maifest editor to check for unused dependencies, the plugin that contains the exported package is listed as unreferenced.
The JUnit plugin test project references three other plugins with no problems, so perhaps there is an issue with the one containing the needed package, but there are no clues in the error logs that there is anything wrong with that plugin. The plugin being tested builds without error, and there are no errors in the errorlog to indicate that there is anything wrong with the plugin.
Let me know what additional information is needed to investigate this problem.

I have resolved the problem, by setting the "Unpack the plug-in archive after installation" option in the feature.xml.
I cleared the unpack option on another plug-in within the feature that I'm testing, and sure enough, the references to that plugin began to generate compile errors. So for now, I have set the feature up with the unpack option set for all plugins within the feature.
Given these results, there may be a user error here. My process is as follows: 1. I'm using an extension location for the feature I'm testing 2. I rebuild the feature using the feature manifest Export Wizard. 3. I copy the generated plugins and features directories into the extension location folder. 4. start a new instance of Eclipse with a test workspace. 5. open the Junit Test project
-- compile errors occur here witn unresolved imports for any plugin within the feature that has the unpack option set false.
I did not sumble over any documentation that says I'm using invalid procedure here, but perhaps I am. If this should work, then maybe this additional info will help identify the bug.

After some discussion in the Platform newsgroup, it was pointed out that I do *NOT* have "." on the classpath. This might result in a failure to loacate META-INF/MANIFEST.MF within the unpacked jar which in turn prevents PDE Build from learning that the nested jar should be searched.
If this is true, then it sounds like PDE Build uses Bundle.getResource() to locate the mainifest which will fail if "." is not on the classpath. If this is true, then perhaps the solution is to add an attempt to use Bundle.getEntry() if the call to getResource() returned null. We know that META-INF/ is at the root of the plugin, so there really is no need locate via classpath.

This seems to be a UI scenario. A couple of comments though: 1) You didn't mention if adding '.' to the Bundle-Classpath resolves your issue. Note that '.' is the default if no Bundle-Classpath is specified. I don't think that having '.' is necessary for finding the manifest in the UI (it isn't in headless pde.build, and sort of presents a chicken-egg problem if it is)
2) From the comment about unpacking the plug-ins, I wonder if you have nested jars, and if the problem is actually bug 147831

(In reply to comment #3) > This seems to be a UI scenario. A couple of comments though: > 1) You didn't mention if adding '.' to the Bundle-Classpath resolves your > issue.
No, it did not.
> 2) From the comment about unpacking the plug-ins, I wonder if you have nested > jars, and if the problem is actually bug 147831
Correct, the issue occurs when the plugin being referenced contains nested jars. As I mentioned in #1 (but possibly not explicitly enough) that building the jar (that I am referencing to) with the unpack option == true, the compile errors are resolved, so yes, this is an issue when referencing plugins that are packed, *and* contain nested jars.
You should probably mark this as a duplicate of 147831.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 147831 ***

bug.short_desc: Bindings and File entries are not removed from the PDOM when corressponding source elements are deleted (implement B-tree delete)

long_desc.thetext:
Where the PDOM maintains B-tree indexes into its content, it needs to delete entries when the corresponding project entity goes away
Most notably PDOMFile objects remain in the index even after the resource has been deleted from the project
(Implementation to follow)

Created an attachment (id=48376) btree delete + unit test
hi,
please find attached a b-tree deletion routine and associated unit test. I've put some javadoc and comments in with the code.
thanks, Andrew

I had a quick go at linking the delete routine into various places in the code just to see what issues arose and this seemed to work ok (from just looking at the Index View)
Some notes: the only issue that came up that might effect a real patch is that for names attached to bindings, the names are deleted without going through the binding, so that the binding contains a pointer to the original list head (even though the corresponding name may have been deleted and free'd). This didn't stop the isOrphaned() method from returning the correct value (which was then used as a sign the binding could be deleted) but am afraid I don't know why
Note: This bugzilla has been generalized to cover both the deletion routine, and its use in the PDOM
There may be a legal issue with the patch, as the algorithm is taken from a book. Are you sure you have the right to do so?

Good point. I was very careful to understand the B-Tree algorithms but write the code myself to avoid copyright issues. The delete is a complicated algorithm which is why I didn't have time to implement it.
I'm confident its not a copyright infringement (the pseudo-code was very high-level - not even functionally complete) - i.e. there are no portions of code that are copied from the book.

Created an attachment (id=51547) b-tree delete implementation, split expensive b-tree tests into separate class
hi,
please find attached an updated version of the previous patch. I've split out the expensive performance tests as suggested.
thanks, Andrew

Great, I can run the tests now. Please externalize the strings you are using. In case they are for debuggin purposes, add $NON-NLS$ tags.
At a few places you are throwing RuntimeExceptions. I don't think this is a good idea. Rather than that you should be throwing an exception that has to be handled by the caller.

Created an attachment (id=51633) externalize strings, and replace RuntimeException->CoreException
now done :)

Thanks Andrew! I have committed the patch.
fixed in 4.0 > 20061009.
I prematurely closed the bug, there is work left to do. While BTree.delete() is implemented, it is not used anywhere.

Yes, this next step is tricky. The idea would be to delete bindings when they are no longer defined, declared, or referenced (isOrphaned() is true). We will need to keep an eye on the performance of incremental indexing when we do this. The whole algorithm may need to change since right now we delete all names in the file that changed, which may lead to removing bindings, and then re-add them which may lead to recreating bindings, which may be a lot more processing that there is now, but then it may not be significant.

some discussion has happened in 167396 and 165636
in addition to deleting bindings from the linkage index on reindex, I think we'd need to
(1) files also need removing from the PDOM file index (2) some IType's need to be deleted e.g. if you have the sequence (i) class A {}; A* c; (ii) class A {}; then at the moment you'll have a floating PDOMCPPPointerType. Maybe subclasses of PDOMCPPVariable should delete the records they reference as types, when its an ITypeContainer (?) (3) https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=167396

in reply to: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=167396#c5
>Would PDOMCPPClassType's delete() remove all of its member bindings too? (methods, fields, etc)
I would say no - on the assertion that when its actually valid to delete a PDOMCPPClassType (isOrphaned()) then the member bindings must also be orphaned? PDOMCPPClassType would still be responsible for deleting its data structure that points to the member bindings though.
I think parameters from functions/methods would be different though as they are currently not PDOMBindings (and so don't have names attached), and also are themselves linked list nodes.
When a project is deleted and all contents also deleted, the PDOM index file in .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.cdt.core should also be deleted.

(In reply to comment #15) > When a project is deleted and all contents also deleted, the PDOM index file in > .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.cdt.core should also be deleted.
This works for me (I tested on Windows against HEAD). Please could you retest/open a new bug with more info (version of CDT, OS)? (This bug is about deletion within the PDOM file)
Due to the fix for bug 193779, IndexBugsTest.test154563() is now passing. However, the bindings are still not removed from the index.

bug.short_desc: DestroyReferenceCommand should not fail if reference end is member of both "normal" and derived EReference's lists

long_desc.thetext:
Consider UML2 Dependency. It has both #targets and #suppliers references. The first one is derived union and always contains the same set of elements as the #suppliers one.
When dependency is mapped into the NodeMapping with links for supplies/clients meta-features, any attempt to delete incoming/outgouing link fails with following (will be attached separately) exception.
It is because DestroyReferenceCommand#doExecuteWithResult method iterates over all of available EReferences and removes target element from all of them. In context of Dependency it tries to remove linkEnd element from both getSuppliers() and getTargets() lists, and the latter attempt fails with UnsupportedOperationException.
In the contexts different from UML2 an attempt to remove element from derived link ends collection will probably fail too though with different stacktrace.
Expected: DestroyReferenceCommand does not try to modify derived EReference's.
Created an attachment (id=48306) Stack trace

Created an attachment (id=48308) Fixes the subj
Just filters the references if ref.isDerived == true.
Changing severity to blocker. There are a lot of derived references in UML diagram (which is part of the proposed MDT project) and this bug severely affects its functionality.
Seems like an easy fix to test out in 1.0.1.

This problem was fixed indirectly by the solution to bug 155233. Now, the DestroyReferenceCommand operates only on features that are set, changeable and not derived.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 155233 ***
Is it possible to deliver the fix into 2.0 stream?
Yes, our plan is to push all of the fixes from 1.0.1 into 2.0 later this month when work in 1.0.1 is finished.
Hmm, there's plan to have 1.0.2 after 1.0.1, perhaps, we should avoid delivering any fixes to 2.0 till done with 1.0.2 ?

Michael, could you have a look at Markus's stack trace? Do you have any idea as to why this is happening? It is just a theory of mine that it could have to do with label providers that spin the event loop, and I am looking for anything that can support or falsify my theory.

All I can really say is that the Team code involved in this stack trace has not undergone any change since 3.1 and this is the first time I have seen a trace like this. Therefore, my guess is it is caused by recent changes elsewhere.

Markus, did this happen at startup or shortly thereafter? Could it be that a label provider (or some of the code it called) tried to acquire a lock that was held by a background job, which caused the "Operation is waiting for a background job" progress dialog to open?
It happened hours after my last startup. However, I have "Always run in background" set to true, and I often cancel blocking compiler jobs (but not other jobs).
Just FYI: I have not seen the exception from comment 6 any more (and I'm not aware of changes in my usage patterns that could have caused this).

Nick had another one of these stack traces, and together we were able to come up with an explanation for at list his case:
Context: It happened in a view that updated itself every five minutes.
1. The first update calls refresh() on a table viewer. 2. In internalRefreshAll(), some of the items are disassociated because their data no longer matches the element at that index 3. After disassociating some or all of the existing items, we do a second pass through the items, bringing back their data and updating their text etc. (It has to be done in two passes or else the element map might end up corrupted.) 4. For one of these items, the label provider threw a NPE and we opened an error dialog. This dialog spins the event loop, which is bad because it allows others to post asyncExecs when we don't expect it. (Also, Nick was not at his computer when the error dialog came up, so it stayed up for some time.) 5. One of those asyncExecs happened to be (after 5 minutes) the next refresh, calling into TableViewer reentrantly. This is bad because: 6. At this time, some items did not have associated data, which caused assertion failures.
What we can do is: - don't open a modal error dialog for every exception happening in label providers - detect cases where viewer code is called reentrantly and ignore the second update request, logging the error because we consider it a programming error to spin the event loop from within a label provider.
Target milestone was set to 3.2M5 but should be 3.3M5.
Moving to M6
*** Bug 173535 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created an attachment (id=62175) patch
Patch released >20070327, to see what this does to the nightly build.

We'll have to see how this plays out. With this patch, reentrant calls to public methods are detected, logged, and then ignored. As explained in comment 12, this can happen if label providers/content providers call back into the viewer, or if they spin the event loop which then causes asyncExecs to run. When I last talked with Nick about this, our consensus was that it is safer to ignore these calls than to try and process them because otherwise the viewer's data structures can be corrupted.
We should also punt the error dialog in SafeRunnable, or avoid using it in the viewers, if that hasn't been done already.
Created an attachment (id=62287) next patch (incremental)

(In reply to comment #18) > We should also punt the error dialog in SafeRunnable, or avoid using it in the > viewers, if that hasn't been done already.
Yes. See bug 168301.
I have reverted both patches - it turned out to be more complicated than I thought. I have another idea for how to approach this, which I hope to implement tomorrow.

Created an attachment (id=65145) patch
New attempt, less ambitious...
Patch released >20070426-0010. (I.e. it is not in the midnight I build.)
Verified - we are seeing useful stack traces being reported now (see e.g. bug 184991)

This change has caused a serious problem for EMF. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=191010
It's not unusual for label computations to reference data that might cause proxies to resolve and such a resolve can lead to resources being loaded, which then updates the view to show these new resource as children. This has never caused a problem, but now it's broken. If we could detect that a viewer is busy, we could minimize the impact of changes we make to EMF, but since we can't know a viewer is busy, we can't know an attempt to update it will fail and that we must try later. So while this fix may have fixed a problem for someone, it's not a problem we ever saw manifested, but now we do have a problem that requires us to make significant changes to the update behavior that I'm not totally comfortable with.
So this change has caused problems we didn't have before and if we react, we may well cause new problems for those downstream from us. Would you consider making isBusy available for clients?

I talked to Ed and he said he is investigating possible fixes on their side. I would suggest continuing the discussion on bug 191010. If it turns out to be too difficult or risky to fix this in EMF, that bug can be given to us. We need to act quickly though, we are in the last week for 3.3!

Pls assign it to the new owner of Automation framework

bug.short_desc: The FacesServlet class name is hardcoded to javax.faces.webapp.FacesServlet

long_desc.thetext:
When creating a new web project with the JSF facet, the FacesServlet servlet is declared in the web.xml using the hardcoded classname 'javax.faces.webapp.FacesServlet'. (see JSFFacetInstallDelegate class)
However, our JSF implementation uses a custom servlet with a different classname, so the web.xml must be manually edited to change the servlet class name for each new project.
It seems like the FacesServlet servlet-class needs to be declared when creating the implementation 'JSF Library'. Then the JSF install delegate should get the FacesServlet servlet-class from the selected implementation JSF library.

Eric,
Would you characterize this as a blocker? Is your severity set high enough?
To fix this I propose that meta-data be added to an JSF implementation libary that is used when setting the web.xml entry at facet installation time.
Unfortunately this would be considered an API change that would make it difficult to get into 1.5.1. That sort of thing is highly discouraged in a maintenance release.
I see from 154573 that you may have other requirements that are related to JSF facet installation and JSF Libs. If you like, please create a bugzilla entry that lists all of the enhancements that you would like to see. The JSF Tools team is in the process of gathering requirements for the next major release and would love to hear and consider all of the suggestions that you may have.
Regards, Gerry Kessler

Well, we are able to workaround the problem, so it is technically not currently blocking us. We have a custom facet that is adding some extra configuration and we are able to programmatically update the servlet-class in there. Would prefer to get rid of that hack eventually though.
As you suggested, I will file another bugzilla in the next few days with some other suggestions/nitpicks that I have run accross.
Thanks, Eric
Triaged for WTP 2.0
fixed for M6 build

bug.short_desc: Selectable Connections

long_desc.thetext: It would be good to have connections that could be selected. This would involve both visual feedback as well as integration with selection services.

bug.short_desc: Add new content providers

long_desc.thetext: An Adjacency Matrix content provider should be added to Zest. Any other ones?

I was thinking about it this morning, and it seems to me that the IGraphEntityContentProvider is, really, the same as an adjacency matrix content provider--if the implementer of it uses it properly. I'm going to test out the provider in a minute, and I'll use an adjacency matrix. I'll post the code later.
Created an attachment (id=48914) A graph model that uses adjacency matrixes

Created an attachment (id=48915) A content provider that uses the adjacency matrix.
This content provider uses and adjacency matrix as the underlying graph. IGraphContentProvider could be used as well. Both would end with the same running time of O(n^2) to generate all of the graph visuals. The problem is that most of the processing to figure out what the nodes/relationships are is left to the user (the user has to scan the model to find the relationships). Also, IGraphEntityContentProvider doesn't allow for multiple relationships for <x,y>. It only allows one in each direction.
There could be a more intuitive node-centric content provider. I'll mock one up quickly, and send it as an attachment.

Created an attachment (id=48927) A node-relationship centric content provider
Here is a possible content provider that would be useful for graph models that are conceptually node-based. The user first gives all of the nodes that are in the graph, and then is asked for the different relationships for each node pair (in both directions). It is up to the user to store relavent information about the relationships.
Created an attachment (id=48928) A sample of how the above content provider would be used.
This was fixed in Bug# 156617.
Changing resolution to "later" in case other content providers are suggested.

attachment.desc: A graph model that uses adjacency matrixes
A content provider that uses the adjacency matrix.
A sample of how the above content provider would be used.

I have fixed this by not zooming fonts once we get over a threshold. I will leave this like this for now and we can see if it is working for people on different resolutions. We may need a size option.

bug.short_desc: FacetedProject objects should be cleared when projects are closed/deleted

long_desc.thetext:
Based on my discussions with Chuck Bridgham, cbridgha@us.ibm.com
my scenario was 1. create a bunch of j2ee projects, created some beans & so on, web pages everything. 2. then I deleted the projects and took a snapshot of the java heap in yourkit and found that
instances of the class FacetedProject are still in memory held onto by the ProjectFacetManagerImpl
They are held as shown below
org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.internal.FacetedProject (#0124102a) value of java.util.HashMap$Entry (#019c5dfb) [1] of java.util.HashMap$Entry[16] (#0121bb34) table of java.util.HashMap (#002ad23c) projects of org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.internal.ProjectFacetsManagerImpl (#00fb9f72) impl of org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.FacetedProjectFramework (#0028a004) org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.internal.FacetedProject (#01af38c5) value of java.util.HashMap$Entry (#0093345c) [5] of java.util.HashMap$Entry[16] (#0121bb34) table of java.util.HashMap (#002ad23c) projects of org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.internal.ProjectFacetsManagerImpl (#00fb9f72) impl of org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.FacetedProjectFramework (#0028a004) org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.internal.FacetedProject (#01b12611) value of java.util.HashMap$Entry (#01d9b924) [8] of java.util.HashMap$Entry[16] (#0121bb34) table of java.util.HashMap (#002ad23c) projects of org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.internal.ProjectFacetsManagerImpl (#00fb9f72) impl of org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.FacetedProjectFramework (#0028a004)

When the listener fires, the FacetedProject.refresh() method is invoked. If the underlying faceted project metadata file no longer exists, the refresh method will clear out the faceted project data structure. The gutted faceted project instance is intentionally kept around in the cache in order to afford continuity for folks registering listeners on this interface and to prevent unmanaged instances of the faceted project class from floating around in memory. This is similar to how the platform handles IProject instances. If you create a project, deleted, and the create another project with the same name, you will notice that the IProject instance is the same.
I will, however, apply the same perf fix here as was implemented for the FlexibleProjectContainer to reduce the number of events handled by the listener.

Actually, the same perf optimization is not going to work here. When I switched the event type from POST_CHANGE to PRE_BUILD as was done for the FlexibleProjectContainer, the testReactionToProjectDelete unit test started failing. Unfortunately, I don't see any other way short of using POST_CHANGE to get notified when a project is deleted. There is a PRE_DELETE, but there is no separate POST_DELETE.

I was wondering why have the faceted project around, if the only reason you have it around is you are hoping a project is created later with the same name at which point you can reuse the FacetedProject instance ?
Even if so, are you sure that the instance is stateless, I wouldnt want the listeners on it to hang around ?
This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP bugs which are in the resolved state without an appropriate targeted version. If you feel this bug was closed inappropriately, please reopen.
