bug.short_desc: [jar exporter] minimise eclipse while create jar is running prevents eclipse from being accessable

long_desc.thetext:
Reproducibility: Periodically, it seems to only be reproducible when the jar tool doesn't already have the code compiled. I haven't figured out how to consistently reproduce the problem. It only seems to be a problem when eclipse actually minimizes before the create jar background thread is finished.
How to reproduce: Using the Create Jar tool in eclipse compile a jar that will have warnings. Right click on the *.jardesc file and click create jar. Onces it is started minimize eclipse. Once the jar process is complete and the warning dialog "is suppose to popup" eclipse is no longer accessible. alt-tab may or may not show eclipse in the application list and clicking on eclipse in the task bar does nothing. Using task manager, selecting the application and choosing switch to will bring eclipse and the warning dialog back to a usable state but I could not find another way to get back to eclipse. I think this is related to the modal dialog being tied to the eclipse window so if eclipse is not showing (it is minimized) when the dialog is shown the entire application is no longer accessible. Except through the task manager -> switch to functionality.

I can't exaclty reproduce but I have an idea. The warning dialog isn't correctly rooted and might show up somewhere on the desktop where it can't be found. I fixed that > 20060829
If you still see the problem after I20060829, would it be possible to start eclipse on a console and make a stacktrace when that happens?
- open command prompt, cd yourEclipseInstall\eclipse - 'java -jar startup.jar' - reproduce the problem, press CTRL + BREAK when eclipse hangs - get the stacktrace from the console

I also saw this same problem with the find/install dialog. If I choose find/install then before the dialog opens use the Windows key - M to minimize eclipse it will get into the same state where the only way to get back to having eclipse visible/open is to use the task manager - switch to functionality as described previously.
I haven't had a chance to test the latest build to see if it fixes the jar creator problem.

I tested again in eclipse milestone release 3.3 M3 the behavior has definitely changed but is still not ideal. Now eclipse still stays in the task bar and in the alt-tab list but will not restore from minimize. The current behavior is actually much worse because you cannot get back to eclipse even by using the switch to functionality in the task manager. Eclipse becomes completely inaccessible and must be closed and opened to return to normal usability.
To recap: Run create jar wizard. While running use Windows key - M to minimize all applications. The warning dialog now does come up at the end, click ok. Eclipse will no longer restore. You cannot get back to eclipse via alt tab, clicking on the task bar button, or using switch to in the task manager. You can exit eclipse normally by right clicking on the task bar button and selecting close so the process is still responding properly it just won't restore from being minimized. Upon opening eclipse again it opens as a tiny title bar in the upper left corner of the screen. I will attach a screen shot.
This behavior does not seem to be exhibited in the find install wizard in the 3.3 M3 release.
Additional info on my config: I run eclipse stretched across two monitors Windows XP with all the latest patches including ie 7 This is a fresh install of eclipse with only dbedit and sysdeo tomcat plugins installed
Let me know if there is more I can assist with

Created an attachment (id=53560) Tiny eclipse
screen shot of tiny eclipse after opening again

We tried to reproduce this here, but minimize all (Windows + M) is blocked while the JAR exporter is running. It can also be seen that the minimize button is disabled. Looks more like a bug in Windows to me. I don;t think we can do anything here.
Moving to SWT, maybe they have more information.
CAR, can you make this happen?
Nope. Same result as Martin in comment 5.

The tiny and useless Eclipse window is what happens when you minimize a dialog shell (ie. a shell that has another shell as a parent). You are never supposed to do this but Windows lets you create the minimize button.
I can't hit Windows-M either. Not sure how to proceed? We can't run your exact case.

I was still able to reproduce in eclipse 3.3 build I20061102-1715 with minimal plugins installed (dbedit, jadeclipse and sysdeo tomcat plugin). I cannot reproduce it often either. The only time i have been able to reproduce is when i have not built the jar in quite a while. The jar i am building uses source from multiple projects. It seems that if I happen to his Windows-M at just the right time it will actually minimize eclipse while the jar is being built. It seems to be more reproducible when you hit Windows-M multiple times. Sometimes it happens when eclipse is not in the foreground. I am running eclipse stretched across multiple monitors and the complete dialog pops up on the secondary monitor.
I'm not sure what other details I can provide. If there is something else that would be helpful I would be glad to help out. Most of the time when I run the jar creator I see the behavior outlined in comment 5.

bug.short_desc: SetConfig unexpectedly asserts "AC configured for security", and ChkPass not shipped

long_desc.thetext:
Just downloaded the agentctrl.linux_ia32-TPTP-4.3.0, unzipped, set LD_LIBRARY_PATH, edited agents/*/agent.xml files, and ran SetConfig. After accepting default for "Security enabled" (FALSE), at the end SetConfig asserts that: "Agent Controller has been configured for security.", asks for the root password, then objects that chown & chmod fail: "cannot access `ChkPass': No such file or directory". I confirm that the security directory only has generateKey.bat and generateKey.sh if that is where they are supposed to go.
I've not tested this on Windows yet.
(Serviceconfig.xml does properly show "SecurityEnabled" as "false" so that it is taking the default correctly.)

Need this fixed before we begin to replace 4.3 RAC with AC for Linux 32 on the download site and request wider testing.
Targetting 4.3 i2 - but need it sooner rather than later in that time frame.

I need to change src-native/collection/packaging/bin/SetConfig.sh to say
RAC_SECURED=`grep -c '<Security ' ../config/serviceconfig.xml` #### NOTE THE *SPACE* after Security!! AC_SECURED=`grep -c '<SecurityEnabled>true' ../config/serviceconfig.xml` SECURED=`expr $RAC_SECURED + $AC_SECURED`
instead of the single check for '<Security' (without the space) that works for the RAC but not for us in "new tech AC"-land.
I've tested both ways (security enabled and not) on both (AC and RAC) and this appears to work perfectly. Just waiting for Samson to confirm he sees no problem before checking in.

bug.short_desc: PDE Tools > Update Classpath deletes Access-Rules

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse 3.2
Whenever I run "Update Classpath..." on my Plugin, all defined access-rules get removed.
Ben
can we see a 'before' and 'after' snapshots of the .classpath file please?

Sure!
Before: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <classpath> <classpathentry kind="src" path="src"/> <classpathentry sourcepath="src.zip" kind="lib" path="h2.jar"/> <classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER/org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.launcher.StandardVMType/J2SE-1.5"/> <classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.pde.core.requiredPlugins"> <accessrules> <accessrule kind="accessible" pattern="**"/> </accessrules> </classpathentry> <classpathentry kind="output" path="bin"/> </classpath>
After: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <classpath> <classpathentry kind="src" path="src"/> <classpathentry sourcepath="src.zip" kind="lib" path="h2.jar"/> <classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER/org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.launcher.StandardVMType/J2SE-1.5"/> <classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.pde.core.requiredPlugins"/> <classpathentry kind="output" path="bin"/> </classpath>
yes, we should respect the attributes added by the user.
Chris, can you take a look at this one when you look at 155315.
The same problem just happened to us with Eclipse 3.3M5 -- it's a nasty one and broke our N-build. I'd love to see that fixed in 3.3.
Darin, this might be interesting for someone to do, not so complicated and gives good exposure to PDE/JDT related things.

Created an attachment (id=79412) Work in progress
Changes the classpath computer to check the project for an existing JRE classpath entry. If one is found, the access rules, extra attributes and exported boolean from the existing entry are applied to the new one.

The current patch solves the original problem. But before this patch should be put in, we must decide when user defined rules should be copied into the new entry. Possible solutions are:
1) Never copy user rules (current behaviour). This is annoying and the reason why this bug was filed in the first place. 2) Only copy rules if the new classpath entry has the same path as the old classpath entry. This would work for the specific case in comment 2, but would throw out the rules if the entry changes in any way (ex. rules defined on a JRE would be tossed as the new entry will use an EE). 3) Always copy the rules (behaviour in the patch). Helpful because it always saves your rules. However, does it really make sense to apply the rules set on a Sun 1.4.2 JRE to a 1.5 EE entry? 4) ...? Come up with some way of knowing if the rules should be added to the new entry.
Option (2) is the safest way to solve the original problem. (3) Seems like a better solution, but only if it is not going to cause problems.
Would anyone like to comment?
Not going to make it for M3, but even if the perfect solution can't be found, something that solves the given case should be put in for M4.
Brian, M4 or should we bump to M5?
I should have pushed to get this looked at earlier in M4. However, this bug is not a major issue and so we'll have to put it off for M5.

bug.short_desc: [Help] parsing error using help.buildHelpIndex

long_desc.thetext:
getting a parsing error on one file when running the help.buildHelpIndex. using org.eclipse.releng.tools.3.2.0.v20060605
I am using customBuildCallBacks. I call the help.buildHelpIndex inside post.build.jars with this line: <help.buildHelpIndex manifest="plugin.xml" destination="."/>
post.build.jars: [subant] Exiting D:\CCBbuild\UATESTbuild\czn-doc\V70D\20060821_1420\pde-build\plugins\com.ibm.etools.portal.doc\buildCustomDITAdoc.xml. [subant] Failure for target 'post.build.jars' of: D:\CCBbuild\UATESTbuild\czn-doc\V70D\20060821_1420\pde-build\plugins\com.ibm.etools.portal.doc\buildCustomDITAdoc.xml [subant] The following error occurred while executing this line: [subant] D:\CCBbuild\UATESTbuild\czn-doc\V70D\20060821_1420\pde-build\plugins\com.ibm.etools.portal.doc\buildCustomDITAdoc.xml:30: Error parsing PortalServer_toc.ditamap. [ant] Exiting D:\CCBbuild\UATESTbuild\czn-doc\V70D\20060821_1420\pde-build\plugins\com.ibm.etools.portal.doc\build.xml.
i will attempt to attach the offending file as soon as I commit this bug. other files don't get this error. and the ditamap in question works for other processes, with no parsing error
Created an attachment (id=48320) file causing parsing error
UA provides this custom Ant task.

The problem appears to be in your PortalServer_toc.ditamap file; it's complaining that it's unable to parse the file:
D:\CCBbuild\UATESTbuild\czn-doc\V70D\20060821_1420\pde-build\plugins\com.ibm.etools.portal.doc\buildCustomDITAdoc.xml:30: Error parsing PortalServer_toc.ditamap.
If this message isn't accurate and it's actually failing in the ant task, please reopen and see if you can provide a sample or some way for me to reproduce the problem (e.g. the generated content from your DITA tools).
I renamed the file to PortalSvr_toc.ditamap. Now, the buildHelpIndex runs, without failing on that file. I did not change the contents of the file in any way.
Were you trying to run buildHelpIndex on a dita file? Eclipse knows nothing about DITA and requires that you convert to HTML, toc XML, etc in order to be indexed by help.

I am running it against my plugin. The plugin contains source files (.dita and .ditamap), as well as the built files (.xml, .html). Is there a way to tell the helpindexer to only try to read .xml, .html, .xhtml ?

this is very odd. I ran the PDE Tools > Create Help Index on the plugin after I renamed the .ditamap file. It created the index once. Now, it's back to complaining about not being able to parse the .ditamap file, and it won't make the index files. Using the PDE Tools interface, as well as using the Ant task.

I would suggest trying to separate the steps of conversion from DITA and indexing of documents so we can see exactly which one is failing. Try generating your TOC and HTML files, without indexing anything, and if that works, clear out all your dita content and try to index.
The indexer will read your TOC as well as any documents in your extraDocs directory specified in the toc extension to decide which documents to index.

That worked. During the build, after the DITA transform step, and before I run the buildHelpIndex task, I deleted the .ditamap, .maplist, .ditaval, and .dita files. The index files now create ok.
But, the problem remains when using the PDE Tools > Create Help Index, if the plugin is in DITA source, as you can't delete the source files from the plugin very easily. This is not an immediate problem for me or my team, as we're using the build to generate these index files.
Thanks very much for the help.

argh. Found the problem. The user had a bad entry in the plugin.xml file. instead of PortalServer_toc.xml, it had PortalServer_toc.ditamap. That explains why the index build was trying to read the file.
user error. in plugin.xml, instead of PortalServer_toc.xml, it had PortalServer_toc.ditamap

on closer inspection it seems the problem is that Team->update is running "cvs update -C -d -P" ...

By default, the Team>Update does not perform a standard CVs update. We did this to improvie conflict handling. You can set it to use a standard update by changing the preference on the Team>CVS>Update/Merge preference page.

bug.short_desc: Support MacOS

long_desc.thetext: Supporting MacOS would be really important... as many Ajax developers use that platform.
Copying Javier after discussing MacOS port on bug148323. I may investigate that in the next few weeks.

Need to get the MozillaBrowser SWT plugin (org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser) working on Mac OS X. The important part is figuring out what to pass into nsIBaseWindow.initWindow().
Grant did some investigation and found that passing OS.getControlOwner() of the parent handle should work. So I copied the MozillaBrowser.java from win32_src folder and changed the method getHandle() to return "OS.getControlOwner(handle)". This works for the most part: ATF comes up; I see tree in the DOM Inspector view on the right; and the JavaScript Console and DOM Source views are also working. The glaring issue, though, is that the web page is not visible; the browser view appears as grey.
Grant said he saw a reference to using nsIEventSink to feed received events (such as paints) back to Mozilla. However, nsIEventSink is only available to C++.
Sweet! Would you have a patch? I could look into it. Note that I think it ouwld be best if the patch in bug 158097 (fragments split) is applied first, so the mac code is in its own fragment.
For the Mac code, just copy the Win32 MozillaBrowser.java, and change the getHandle() method to be "return OS.GetControlOwner(handle);".

(In reply to comment #4) > For the Mac code, just copy the Win32 MozillaBrowser.java, and change the > getHandle() method to be "return OS.GetControlOwner(handle);". Nice. And sorry, I should have read comment #3 fully! The proposed Macosx fragment in bug 158097 uses a naive copy of the win MozillaBrowser already. As for the nsIEventSink, you think you could explose that in JavaXPCOM ;-) ?

(In reply to comment #5) > As for the nsIEventSink, you think you could explose that in JavaXPCOM ;-) ?
To hack this, you can create the Java interface yourself, and add it to you MozillaInterfaces.jar.
However, I'm not sure that that is the interface that is needed. It looks to mainly be used for drag-drop operation (http://lxr.mozilla.org/mozilla/search?string=nsIEventSink); nothing to do with painting.

Created an attachment (id=51909) Firefox text draw stack
This is the stack in Firefox when drawing text to the window.
At frame #56, the function nsAppShell::Run() is called, which calls RunApplicationEventLoop in order to kick off the event loop. We don't need to do this in Eclipse, since SWT has its own event loop.
At frame #46, the OS events routine calls into Firefox's nsMacWindow::WindowEventHandler. This handler was registered by calling the OS function InstallWindowEventHandler() in nsMacWindow::StandardCreate(), which is called when creating a new window in Firefox/Mozilla. Of course, none of this happens for SWT since it creates its own windows.
So we need to register Mozilla's event handlers when bringing up the browser. SWT does this already for embedding the Safari browser on Mac OS X (search for 'InstallEventHandler' in http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/org.eclipse.swt/Eclipse%20SWT%20Browser/carbon/org/eclipse/swt/browser/Browser.java?rev=HEAD).

Javier: Note that I have access to G4, G5, Solo, and Du core Macs :-P I would be happy: - to test - to help.
I am copying Scott from Apple who should be interested to track this bug, and might be able to help at times too. Cordially

Here's what I found: The page is drawn when Mozilla receives the kEventWindowUpdate event. Even if I properly register an event handler for that event, it never gets sent to Mozilla. Other events do get sent to Mozilla, such as kEventWindowActivated; so that tells me that the window event registration routines are working properly.
My guess is that SWT is eating the kEventWindowUpdate event before it gets to Mozilla. Is there any way to prevent that? Or is there an SWT update event I can listen for, in order to call the appropriate Mozilla code at that time?

I think the event kEventWindowUpdate is not being sent because the window is in compositing mode (kWindowCompositingAttribute). Does the mozilla browser work in compositing windows? As a quick hack, it is possible to hack SWT so that it does not create compositing windows by setting the org.eclipse.swt.internal.carbon.OS.HIVIEW flag to false.

> org.eclipse.swt.internal.carbon.OS.HIVIEW flag to false.
Do I need to recompile SWT in order to do that, or is there an easier way?
Yes, you need to recompile SWT to try the hack.

Created an attachment (id=53516) HIVIEW hack screenshot
So recompiled SWT with HIVIEW == false, and ran with it. Loading google.com worked as before, in that the browser view was just a solid gray. However, loading cnn.com showed the web page, but offset starting in the upper left (see attached screenshot).
So this seems to go along with what Silenio said. The question is how can I use this knowledge to fix the problem.
From the Apple docs, it looks like windows in compositing mode receive a kEventControlDraw. Can I just treat the whole browser view as one 'control' by registering a kEventControlDraw listener, and then simulate an update event to Mozilla?

Progress: Based on a hint by another developer, and code similar to that in WebClient (http://landfill.mozilla.org/mxr-test/mozilla/source/java/webclient/src_moz/cocoa/CocoaBrowserControlCanvas.mm#38), I wrapped the MozillaBrowser widget in an AWT Frame, from which I was able to retrieve an NSView. I can then call baseWindow.initWindow() with this NSView and get the browser widget to properly draw on Mac. However, this only works for a XULRunner built with Cocoa widgets (which officially is only the trunk [version 1.9] right now).
So this fix will not work with XULRunner 1.8.x, which is built with Carbon widgets. If trying to get this to work for Carbon widgets is too difficult (or not possible), it may just be best to get a XULRunner 1.8.x release built with Cocoa widgets.

Created an attachment (id=53627) MozillaBrowser.java for XULRunner/Mac with Cocoa widgets
This is the Mac implementation of the MozillaBrowser.java class. This depends on the method exposed by the patch in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=335696. As stated in the last comment, this only works in a XULRunner built with Cocoa widgets (v1.9/trunk by default, or a custom built v1.8.x).

Forgot to mention that the code from the last attachment depends on the "SWT Compatibility Libraries for J2SE 5.0 Release 4" from Apple. Unfortunately, you can currently only get those libraries from http://developer.apple.com/ (once logged in, select 'Downloads' and the 'Java' from the right hand side).

I tried to get this running with the latest xulrunner from trunk but mozilla.getServiceManager() and mozilla.getComponentManager() both fail for me when invoked (these work for me with a 1.8.0.x xulrunner). I've locally modified the MozillaBrowser from what's in ATF, but I assume that making these calls after mozilla.initEmbedding() has been called should never fail (?). If not, is there a specific xulrunner trunk build that I should try that is known to work for others?

There was a change in the APIs, where you now need to call the initialize() method, before calling initEmbedding() or any of the other methods. Are you making this call?
Also, even with that change, this still won't work on Mac since the patch in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=335696 hasn't been checked in yet.

If the patch from https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=335696 just adds the getNativeHandleFromAWT method then I shouldn't need it, as I just hacked this part within swt.
However I'm having a hard time finding a recent xulrunner 1.9a nightly build for mac that has the MozillaInterfaces.jar to compile against (I'm looking at http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/xulrunner/nightly/latest-trunk/). I've found older 1.9a ones that have this jar, but they don't have the new Mozilla.initialize() method. As a side note, they also don't have nsIAppShell.create(...) and spinup(); did you change MozillaBrowser to no longer use these?

> ... as I just hacked this part within swt.
What specifically did you do?
> However I'm having a hard time finding a recent xulrunner 1.9a nightly build > for mac that has the MozillaInterfaces.jar to compile against.
A while back, the MozillaInterfaces.jar file was moved from the XR binary distribution to the SDK distribution. Unfortunately, it looks like the Mac XR SDK is not getting copied to the download servers. Download either the Linux or Win32 XR SDK and get the MozillaInterfaces.jar from there.
> As a side note, they also don't have > nsIAppShell.create(...) and spinup(); did you change MozillaBrowser to no > longer use these?
The nsIAppShell interface changed in XR 1.9. I have a patch in https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=160098 for changing the browser code and other ATF classes to work with XR 1.9.

Created an attachment (id=54836) MozillaBrowser.java - focus improvement
Added a listener that syncs focus between the AWT and SWT components. This approach still isn't perfect, and might require more such 'syncing' functions between the AWT and SWT components.
The latest weekly build has support for Mac OS X.

attachment.desc: MozillaBrowser.java for XULRunner/Mac with Cocoa widgets

bug.short_desc: DebugModelContextBindingManager does not use IAdaptable.getAdapter() to retrieve IDebugModelProvider adapter

long_desc.thetext:
Instead it calls Platform.getAdapterManager().getAdapter(). This works for all elements that use the platform adapter manager to register their adapters, but it doesn't work otherwise.
I searched for other instances of where IAdaptable.getAdapter() call might have been omitted, but I didn't find any. So this may be the only omission.
Created an attachment (id=48322) Patch for the offending call.
verified fix and released patch to HEAD.

bug.short_desc: [project explorer] EJB jar groups in PX sorted inappropriately

long_desc.thetext:
Opened for IBM:
I'm not sure wha the design is supposed to be here, but the current implemenation looks wrong. Create a new EJB project and then expand it in the Project Explorer. Under the deployment descriptor you will notice the following nodes in the following order:
Entity Beans Message Driven Beans Session Beans
However, if an adopter contributes a group starting with "Ma" for example, it will be placed right after Entity Beans. I realize it is the alpahbetical sorting, but it just seems like the 3 bean types ought to be grouped together and then adopter groups should be after them.
Created an attachment (id=48413) Proposed patch

The problem is the extended children were being treated the same as the core children. We want to show our base children first, grouped together, and then the extended ones. The sorter has been made a little bit smarter to check the package name to determine if it was contributed by JST or WST. These are referred to as core and are given priority.
Patch attached and ready for review.
Created an attachment (id=48438) updated patch

Approve with the updated patch.
It is getting late in the cycle for changes like this. I am not sure why this was considered a major severity. The description of the defect didn't provide enough detail to warrant the severity level.
approve Dan's patch
approved
Tested updated patch and released for the 082406 WTP 1.5.1 build.
Verified 082806.

bug.short_desc: Completed tasks do not get strikethrough

long_desc.thetext: Completed tasks in the tasklist do not get strikethrough on linux like they do on Windows. I wonder if this is another of those subtle differences in SWT across platforms.

Strikethrough fonts are not supported on all platforms, so we set this as a hint. Windows renders them. Bug 124551 is also related.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 71901 ***
